title: PostDoc Position @NOKIA Bell Labs, @TRiBE/NEO-INRIA
text:
In this postdoc, we will study the problem of AI model placement in an IDN. This is a challenging optimization problem that involves a non-trivial tradeoff between model effectiveness, inference latency, and resource availability while also dealing with the natural dynamicity of the network, e.g., due to users’ request process or changes in available computing and communication resources.
We will also consider other metrics, such as energy consumption, in the objective functions and networking constraints for systems where the network presents some inelasticity (see also [1]). We will leverage multi-objective optimization techniques (e.g., Pareto efficient solutions) and transfer learning techniques to adapt models across nodes with different levels of knowledge and resource availability. We will also rely on online learning approaches to achieve model placements with adversarial guarantees regarding regret.
In comparison to our preliminary work in [2] or [3], we will allow models to be split across multiple nodes [4,5,6]. In particular, we aim to compare specific model splitting techniques, with or without the insertion of bottlenecks [7,8] (reference [8] is also the result of NEO-AIRL cooperation), in terms of performance metrics like inference delay and network load. We will evaluate different methodologies to estimate online the quality of an inference [9].
This evaluation may also consider scenarios with significant heterogeneity of the nodes, such as in the scenario of embedded Edge AI or even more with TinyML (resources possibly lower by orders of magnitude but possibly a massive number of devices).

title: Nadjib Achir
text:
I am a researcher (HDR) at Inria, and a member of the TRiBE team at Inria Saclay.
I was an Associate Professor (HDR) at Université Sorbonne Paris Nord from 2004 to 2024, where I was fully dedicated to the Engineering School and contributed to training in telecommunications and networks, including responsibilities within the SupGalilée engineering school. Since September 2024, I have joined Inria as a full-time researcher.
My recent research work focuses on two complementary directions: (i) collecting and analyzing mobility data, especially through measurements enabled by wireless networks (ii) resource allocation and computation offloading at the edge, to support ultra-responsive applications with strong latency and compute constraints. (iii) Edge AI, where I study how to bring modern ML to constrained IoT systems by leveraging split computing/split inference and dynamic offloading to nearby edge or cloud resources.

title: Projects
text:
NAI – Networks Architecture & Infrastructure and Networks, Cloud, & Sensing Convergence



2023-07-01 -- 2029-06-30



The NAI project designs agile, resource-efficient architectures that merge network, cloud, and sensing capabilities for 5G and 6G. It enables a seamless continuum from edge devices to data centers using advanced orchestration, network slicing, and non-terrestrial integration. This framework supports diverse high-performance applications like Industry 4.0, smart mobility, and digital twins.












FITNESS – From IoT breakthroughs to Network Enhanced ServiceS



2023-07-01 -- 2029-06-30



The FITNESS project develops innovative IoT solutions by optimizing elementary building blocks for massive connectivity, Industry 4.0, and connected transport. It focuses on critical technical constraints such as ultra-low power consumption, high security, and low latency for mission-critical vehicular applications. By ensuring the coexistence of 5G and post-5G protocols, it enables a robust and scalable ecosystem for future digital services.












Mob Sci-Dat Factory


The Mob Sci-Dat Factory builds a shared digital infrastructure to process and analyze heterogeneous mobility data for people and goods. It provides a secure cloud platform with open-source tools to support sustainable decision-making and data sovereignty in French research. This factory aims to unify scientific communities to accelerate the transition toward greener, multimodal transport systems.












MITIK – Mobility and contact traces from non-intrusive passive measurements


The MITIK project utilizes passive wireless sensors to capture spatiotemporal activity and contact traces from mobile devices without intruding on user privacy. It develops advanced methods for context-aware deployment, data anonymization, and the reconstruction of individual trajectories to model human mobility. This research enables a better understanding of social interactions and spatial usage through scientifically rigorous data collection.
